citeinfo.title: Damaged and Destroyed Villages Darfur Sudan 2010
United States. Dept. of State. Humanitarian Information Unit Data

descript.abstract: This point dataset describes the condition of villages in the Darfur region of Sudan that the U.S. Government has confirmed as either "damaged" or "destroyed" between the time period February 2003 to December 2010. Additionally, villages the are confirmed to have "No Damage" are also reported.
descript.purpose: This dataset is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data. This layer may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.
descript.supplinf:
Using the "Darfur Damaged and Destroyed Villages" dataset responsibly: Monitoring the status of villages in Darfur, Sudan is an ongoing process. After information on the level of damage of villages is collected and confirmed, that information goes into a data table in which entire villages are categorized as not damaged, damaged, or destroyed. This categorization process is not an exact science, but the methodology employed is a conservative one; the database only includes records of damage and destruction about which there is a high degree of confidence. All estimates about the number of destroyed structures and total structures are approximate. Wherever possible, the year or year range of damage is included in the database field associated with a particular village, though the database does not contain precise dates of damage or destruction. On occasion the "YR_ATTACK" field will include a date range of two different years, for example "2003/2004". This indicates the date range in which the attack was confirmed, and should not be interpreted that there were multiple attacks.
HIU Modifications: The Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State has reformatted the original dataset, in an attempt to increase its usability for quantitative analysis. The original "Structures" data field was parsed into three seperate fields: "Aprox_Str1", "Aprox_Str2", and "Sec_Town". All efforts were made to ensure these data fields matched the original, but if a difference is found, please defer to the original "Structures" field. As with the original "Structures" data field, all counts are approximate. Additionally the "YR_ATTACK" field was also parsed. In the situation where an exact year could not be determined, the "YR_ATTACK" field was split into two data fields "YR_RANGE1" and "YR_RANGE2". This was done solely with the intent of making numerical calculations easier and should not be interpreted as either additional precision regarding the year of attack or that two seperate attacks occurred. Again, if a discrepancy between the "YR_ATTACK" field and the "YR_RANGE1" and "YR_RANGE2" fields occur, defer to the original "YR_ATTACK" data. When the HIU receives further information on the status of more villages throughout the region, we will distribute it as appropriate. This data can be sourced as "U.S. Government."

cntperp.cntorg: Humanitarian Information Unit, U.S. Department of State

attracc.attraccr: Monitoring the status of villages in Darfur, Sudan is an ongoing process. After information on the level of damage of villages is collected and confirmed, that information goes into a data table in which entire villages are categorized as not damaged, damaged, or destroyed. This categorization process is not an exact science, but the methodology employed is a conservative one; the database only includes records of damage and destruction about which there is a high degree of confidence. All estimates about the number of destroyed structures and total structures are approximate. Wherever possible, the year or year range of damage is included in the database field associated with a particular village, though the database does not contain precise dates of damage or destruction. On occasion the "YR_ATTACK" field will include a date range of two different years, for example "2003/2004". This indicates the date range in which the attack was confirmed, and should not be interpreted that there were multiple attacks.

procstep.procdesc: Changed name of file from HIU_Sudan_Darfur_DamagedDestroyedVillages_2010Dec to Darfurdamvillages10

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Condition of village at time of evaluation
Approximation of both the damaged/destroyed structures and the total number of structures in a village
Year in which village destruction could be confirmed
Parsed from original "Structures" data field, represents the approximate number of destroyed structures in a village
Parsed from original "Structures" data field, represents the approximate total number of structures in a village
year village destruction was confirmed; parsed from original "Yr_Confirm" data field
second date of an approximate year range; parsed from original "Yr_Confirm" data field

attrvai.attrva: if a value appears in "Yr_Range2", it indicates the second date of a date range in which the attack occurred

attr.attrdef: Secondary town is a general description used to differentiate between large and small villages. Secondary towns are generally hubs of activity for the local area.
